t: 1 Kings 1
Now*p king David was old and stricken in years; and they covered him with clothes, but he gat no heat.

Wherefore*p his servants said unto him, Let there be sought for my lord the king a young virgin: and let her stand before the king, and let her cherish him, and let her lie in thy bosom, that my lord the king may get heat.
So*p they sought for a fair damsel throughout all the coasts of Israel, and found Abishag a Shunammite, and brought her to the king.
And*p the damsel was very fair, and cherished the king, and ministered to him: but the king knew her not.
Then*p Adonijah the son of Haggith exalted himself, saying, I will be king: and he prepared him chariots and horsemen, and fifty men to run before him.
And*p his father had not displeased him at any time in saying, Why hast thou done so? and he also was a very goodly man; and his mother bare him after Absalom.
And*p he conferred with Joab the son of Zeruiah, and with Abiathar the priest: and they following Adonijah helped him.
But*p Zadok the priest, and Benaiah the son of Jehoiada, and Nathan the prophet, and Shimei, and Rei, and the mighty men which belonged to David, were not with Adonijah.
And*p Adonijah slew sheep and oxen and fat cattle by the stone of Zoheleth, which is by En–rogel, and called all his brethren the king's sons, and all the men of Judah the king's servants:
But*p Nathan the prophet, and Benaiah, and the mighty men, and Solomon his brother, he called not.
Wherefore*p Nathan spake unto Bath–sheba the mother of Solomon, saying, Hast thou not heard that Adonijah the son of Haggith doth reign, and David our lord knoweth it not?
Now*p therefore come, let me, I pray thee, give thee counsel, that thou mayest save thine own life, and the life of thy son Solomon.

Go*p and get thee in unto king David, and say unto him, Didst not thou, my lord, O king, swear unto thine handmaid, saying, Assuredly Solomon thy son shall reign after me, and he shall sit upon my throne? why then doth Adonijah reign?
Behold,*p while thou yet talkest there with the king, I also will come in after thee, and confirm thy words.
And*p Bath–sheba went in unto the king into the chamber: and the king was very old; and Abishag the Shunammite ministered unto the king.
And*p Bath–sheba bowed, and did obeisance unto the king. And the king said, What wouldest thou?
And*p she said unto him, My lord, thou swarest by the Lord*s thy God unto thine handmaid, saying, Assuredly Solomon thy son shall reign after me, and he shall sit upon my throne.
And*p now, behold, Adonijah reigneth; and now, my lord the king, thou knowest it not:

And*p he hath slain oxen and fat cattle and sheep in abundance, and hath called all the sons of the king, and Abiathar the priest, and Joab the captain of the host: but Solomon thy servant hath he not called.
And*p thou, my lord, O king, the eyes of all Israel are upon thee, that thou shouldest tell them who shall sit on the throne of my lord the king after him.
Otherwise*p it shall come to pass, when my lord the king shall sleep with his fathers, that I and my son Solomon shall be counted offenders.
And,*p lo, while she yet talked with the king, Nathan the prophet also came in.
And*p they told the king, saying, Behold Nathan the prophet. And when he was come in before the king, he bowed himself before the king with his face to the ground.
And*p Nathan said, My lord, O king, hast thou said, Adonijah shall reign after me, and he shall sit upon my throne?

For*p he is gone down this day, and hath slain oxen and fat cattle and sheep in abundance, and hath called all the king's sons, and the captains of the host, and Abiathar the priest; and, behold, they eat and drink before him, and say, God save king Adonijah.
But*p me, even me thy servant, and Zadok the priest, and Benaiah the son of Jehoiada, and thy servant Solomon, hath he not called.
Is*p this thing done by my lord the king, and thou hast not shewed it unto thy servant, who should sit on the throne of my lord the king after him?
Then*p king David answered and said, Call me Bath–sheba. And she came into the king's presence, and stood before the king.
And*p the king sware, and said, As the Lord*s liveth, that hath redeemed my soul out of all distress,
Even*p as I sware unto thee by the Lord*s God of Israel, saying, Assuredly Solomon thy son shall reign after me, and he shall sit upon my throne in my stead; even so will I certainly do this day.
Then*p Bath–sheba bowed with her face to the earth, and did reverence to the king, and said, Let my lord king David live for ever.
And*p king David said, Call me Zadok the priest, and Nathan the prophet, and Benaiah the son of Jehoiada. And they came before the king.
The*p king also said unto them, Take with you the servants of your lord, and cause Solomon my son to ride upon mine own mule, and bring him down to Gihon:
And*p let Zadok the priest and Nathan the prophet anoint him there king over Israel: and blow ye with the trumpet, and say, God save king Solomon.
Then*p ye shall come up after him, that he may come and sit upon my throne; for he shall be king in my stead: and I have appointed him to be ruler over Israel and over Judah.
And*p Benaiah the son of Jehoiada answered the king, and said, Amen: the Lord*s God of my lord the king say so too.
As*p the Lord*s hath been with my lord the king, even so be he with Solomon, and make his throne greater than the throne of my lord king David.

So*p Zadok the priest, and Nathan the prophet, and Benaiah the son of Jehoiada, and the Cherethites, and the Pelethites, went down, and caused Solomon to ride upon king David's mule, and brought him to Gihon.
And*p Zadok the priest took an horn of oil out of the tabernacle, and anointed Solomon. And they blew the trumpet; and all the people said, God save king Solomon.
And*p all the people came up after him, and the people piped with pipes, and rejoiced with great joy, so that the earth rent with the sound of them.

And*p Adonijah and all the guests that were with him heard it as they had made an end of eating. And when Joab heard the sound of the trumpet, he said, Wherefore is this noise of the city being in an uproar?
And*p while he yet spake, behold, Jonathan the son of Abiathar the priest came: and Adonijah said unto him, Come in; for thou art a valiant man, and bringest good tidings.
And*p Jonathan answered and said to Adonijah, Verily our lord king David hath made Solomon king.

And*p the king hath sent with him Zadok the priest, and Nathan the prophet, and Benaiah the son of Jehoiada, and the Cherethites, and the Pelethites, and they have caused him to ride upon the king's mule:
And*p Zadok the priest and Nathan the prophet have anointed him king in Gihon: and they are come up from thence rejoicing, so that the city rang again. This is the noise that ye have heard.
And*p also Solomon sitteth on the throne of the kingdom.

And*p moreover the king's servants came to bless our lord king David, saying, God make the name of Solomon better than thy name, and make his throne greater than thy throne. And the king bowed himself upon the bed.
And*p also thus said the king, Blessed be the Lord*s God of Israel, which hath given one to sit on my throne this day, mine eyes even seeing it.
And*p all the guests that were with Adonijah were afraid, and rose up, and went every man his way.
And*p Adonijah feared because of Solomon, and arose, and went, and caught hold on the horns of the altar.

And*p it was told Solomon, saying, Behold, Adonijah feareth king Solomon: for, lo, he hath caught hold on the horns of the altar, saying, Let king Solomon swear unto me to day that he will not slay his servant with the sword.
And*p Solomon said, If he will shew himself a worthy man, there shall not an hair of him fall to the earth: but if wickedness shall be found in him, he shall die.
So*p king Solomon sent, and they brought him down from the altar. And he came and bowed himself to king Solomon: and Solomon said unto him, Go to thine house.
1 Kings 2
Now*p the days of David drew nigh that he should die; and he charged Solomon his son, saying,
I*p go the way of all the earth: be thou strong therefore, and shew thyself a man;

And*p keep the charge of the Lord*s thy God, to walk in his ways, to keep his statutes, and his commandments, and his judgments, and his testimonies, as it is written in the law of Moses, that thou mayest prosper in all that thou doest, and whithersoever thou turnest thyself:

That*p the Lord*s may continue his word which he spake concerning me, saying, If thy children take heed to their way, to walk before me in truth with all their heart and with all their soul, there shall not fail thee (said he) a man on the throne of Israel.

Moreover*p thou knowest also what Joab the son of Zeruiah did to me, and what he did to the two captains of the hosts of Israel, unto Abner the son of Ner, and unto Amasa the son of Jether, whom he slew, and shed the blood of war in peace, and put the blood of war upon his girdle that was about his loins, and in his shoes that were on his feet.
Do*p therefore according to thy wisdom, and let not his hoar head go down to the grave in peace.
But*p shew kindness unto the sons of Barzillai the Gileadite, and let them be of those that eat at thy table: for so they came to me when I fled because of Absalom thy brother.

And,*p behold, thou hast with thee Shimei the son of Gera, a Benjamite of Bahurim, which cursed me with a grievous curse in the day when I went to Mahanaim: but he came down to meet me at Jordan, and I sware to him by the Lord,*s saying, I will not put thee to death with the sword.
Now*p therefore hold him not guiltless: for thou art a wise man, and knowest what thou oughtest to do unto him; but his hoar head bring thou down to the grave with blood.
So*p David slept with his fathers, and was buried in the city of David.
And*p the days that David reigned over Israel were forty years: seven years reigned he in Hebron, and thirty and three years reigned he in Jerusalem.
Then*p sat Solomon upon the throne of David his father; and his kingdom was established greatly.
And*p Adonijah the son of Haggith came to Bath–sheba the mother of Solomon. And she said, Comest thou peaceably? And he said, Peaceably.
He*p said moreover, I have somewhat to say unto thee. And she said, Say on.

And*p he said, Thou knowest that the kingdom was mine, and that all Israel set their faces on me, that I should reign: howbeit the kingdom is turned about, and is become my brother's: for it was his from the Lord.*s
And*p now I ask one petition of thee, deny me not. And she said unto him, Say on.
And*p he said, Speak, I pray thee, unto Solomon the king, (for he will not say thee nay,) that he give me Abishag the Shunammite to wife.
And*p Bath–sheba said, Well; I will speak for thee unto the king.

Bath–sheba*p therefore went unto king Solomon, to speak unto him for Adonijah. And the king rose up to meet her, and bowed himself unto her, and sat down on his throne, and caused a seat to be set for the king's mother; and she sat on his right hand.
Then*p she said, I desire one small petition of thee; I pray thee, say me not nay. And the king said unto her, Ask on, my mother: for I will not say thee nay.
And*p she said, Let Abishag the Shunammite be given to Adonijah thy brother to wife.

And*p king Solomon answered and said unto his mother, And why dost thou ask Abishag the Shunammite for Adonijah? ask for him the kingdom also; for he is mine elder brother; even for him, and for Abiathar the priest, and for Joab the son of Zeruiah.
Then*p king Solomon sware by the Lord,*s saying, God do so to me, and more also, if Adonijah have not spoken this word against his own life.
Now*p therefore, as the Lord*s liveth, which hath established me, and set me on the throne of David my father, and who hath made me an house, as he promised, Adonijah shall be put to death this day.
And*p king Solomon sent by the hand of Benaiah the son of Jehoiada; and he fell upon him that he died.

And*p unto Abiathar the priest said the king, Get thee to Anathoth, unto thine own fields; for thou art worthy of death: but I will not at this time put thee to death, because thou barest the ark of the Lord God*s before David my father, and because thou hast been afflicted in all wherein my father was afflicted.
So*p Solomon thrust out Abiathar from being priest unto the Lord;*s that he might fulfil the word of the Lord,*s which he spake concerning the house of Eli in Shiloh.
Then*p tidings came to Joab: for Joab had turned after Adonijah, though he turned not after Absalom. And Joab fled unto the tabernacle of the Lord,*s and caught hold on the horns of the altar.
And*p it was told king Solomon that Joab was fled unto the tabernacle of the Lord;*s and, behold, he is by the altar. Then Solomon sent Benaiah the son of Jehoiada, saying, Go, fall upon him.

And*p Benaiah came to the tabernacle of the Lord,*s and said unto him, Thus saith the king, Come forth. And he said, Nay; but I will die here. And Benaiah brought the king word again, saying, Thus said Joab, and thus he answered me.
And*p the king said unto him, Do as he hath said, and fall upon him, and bury him; that thou mayest take away the innocent blood, which Joab shed, from me, and from the house of my father.

And*p the Lord*s shall return his blood upon his own head, who fell upon two men more righteous and better than he, and slew them with the sword, my father David not knowing thereof, to wit, Abner the son of Ner, captain of the host of Israel, and Amasa the son of Jether, captain of the host of Judah.

Their*p blood shall therefore return upon the head of Joab, and upon the head of his seed for ever: but upon David, and upon his seed, and upon his house, and upon his throne, shall there be peace for ever from the Lord.*s
So*p Benaiah the son of Jehoiada went up, and fell upon him, and slew him: and he was buried in his own house in the wilderness.
And*p the king put Benaiah the son of Jehoiada in his room over the host: and Zadok the priest did the king put in the room of Abiathar.
And*p the king sent and called for Shimei, and said unto him, Build thee an house in Jerusalem, and dwell there, and go not forth thence any whither.
For*p it shall be, that on the day thou goest out, and passest over the brook Kidron, thou shalt know for certain that thou shalt surely die: thy blood shall be upon thine own head.
And*p Shimei said unto the king, The saying is good: as my lord the king hath said, so will thy servant do. And Shimei dwelt in Jerusalem many days.
And*p it came to pass at the end of three years, that two of the servants of Shimei ran away unto Achish son of Maachah king of Gath. And they told Shimei, saying, Behold, thy servants be in Gath.
And*p Shimei arose, and saddled his ass, and went to Gath to Achish to seek his servants: and Shimei went, and brought his servants from Gath.
And*p it was told Solomon that Shimei had gone from Jerusalem to Gath, and was come again.

And*p the king sent and called for Shimei, and said unto him, Did I not make thee to swear by the Lord,*s and protested unto thee, saying, Know for a certain, on the day thou goest out, and walkest abroad any whither, that thou shalt surely die? and thou saidst unto me, The word that I have heard is good.
Why*p then hast thou not kept the oath of the Lord,*s and the commandment that I have charged thee with?

The*p king said moreover to Shimei, Thou knowest all the wickedness which thine heart is privy to, that thou didst to David my father: therefore the Lord*s shall return thy wickedness upon thine own head;
And*p king Solomon shall be blessed, and the throne of David shall be established before the Lord*s for ever.
So*p the king commanded Benaiah the son of Jehoiada; which went out, and fell upon him, that he died. And the kingdom was established in the hand of Solomon.
1 Kings 3

And*p Solomon made affinity with Pharaoh king of Egypt, and took Pharaoh's daughter, and brought her into the city of David, until he had made an end of building his own house, and the house of the Lord,*s and the wall of Jerusalem round about.
Only*p the people sacrificed in high places, because there was no house built unto the name of the Lord,*s until those days.
And*p Solomon loved the Lord,*s walking in the statutes of David his father: only he sacrificed and burnt incense in high places.
And*p the king went to Gibeon to sacrifice there; for that was the great high place: a thousand burnt offerings did Solomon offer upon that altar.
In*p Gibeon the Lord*s appeared to Solomon in a dream by night: and God said, Ask what I shall give thee.

And*p Solomon said, Thou hast shewed unto thy servant David my father great mercy, according as he walked before thee in truth, and in righteousness, and in uprightness of heart with thee; and thou hast kept for him this great kindness, that thou hast given him a son to sit on his throne, as it is this day.
And*p now, O Lord*s my God, thou hast made thy servant king instead of David my father: and I am but a little child: I know not how to go out or come in.
And*p thy servant is in the midst of thy people which thou hast chosen, a great people, that cannot be numbered nor counted for multitude.
Give*p therefore thy servant an understanding heart to judge thy people, that I may discern between good and bad: for who is able to judge this thy so great a people?
And*p the speech pleased the Lord, that Solomon had asked this thing.

And*p God said unto him, Because thou hast asked this thing, and hast not asked for thyself long life; neither hast asked riches for thyself, nor hast asked the life of thine enemies; but hast asked for thyself understanding to discern judgment;
Behold,*p I have done according to thy words: lo, I have given thee a wise and an understanding heart; so that there was none like thee before thee, neither after thee shall any arise like unto thee.
And*p I have also given thee that which thou hast not asked, both riches, and honour: so that there shall not be any among the kings like unto thee all thy days.
And*p if thou wilt walk in my ways, to keep my statutes and my commandments, as thy father David did walk, then I will lengthen thy days.

And*p Solomon awoke; and, behold, it was a dream. And he came to Jerusalem, and stood before the ark of the covenant of the Lord,*s and offered up burnt offerings, and offered peace offerings, and made a feast to all his servants.
Then*p came there two women, that were harlots, unto the king, and stood before him.
And*p the one woman said, O my lord, I and this woman dwell in one house; and I was delivered of a child with her in the house.
And*p it came to pass the third day after that I was delivered, that this woman was delivered also: and we were together; there was no stranger with us in the house, save we two in the house.
And*p this woman's child died in the night; because she overlaid it.
And*p she arose at midnight, and took my son from beside me, while thine handmaid slept, and laid it in her bosom, and laid her dead child in my bosom.
And*p when I rose in the morning to give my child suck, behold, it was dead: but when I had considered it in the morning, behold, it was not my son, which I did bear.
And*p the other woman said, Nay; but the living is my son, and the dead is thy son. And this said, No; but the dead is thy son, and the living is my son. Thus they spake before the king.
Then*p said the king, The one saith, This is my son that liveth, and thy son is the dead: and the other saith, Nay; but thy son is the dead, and my son is the living.
And*p the king said, Bring me a sword. And they brought a sword before the king.
And*p the king said, Divide the living child in two, and give half to the one, and half to the other.

Then*p spake the woman whose the living child was unto the king, for her bowels yearned upon her son, and she said, O my lord, give her the living child, and in no wise slay it. But the other said, Let it be neither mine nor thine, but divide it.
Then*p the king answered and said, Give her the living child, and in no wise slay it: she is the mother thereof.
And*p all Israel heard of the judgment which the king had judged; and they feared the king: for they saw that the wisdom of God was in him, to do judgment.
1 Kings 4
So*p king Solomon was king over all Israel.
And*p these were the princes which he had; Azariah the son of Zadok the priest,
Elihoreph*p and Ahiah, the sons of Shisha, scribes; Jehoshaphat the son of Ahilud, the recorder.
And*p Benaiah the son of Jehoiada was over the host: and Zadok and Abiathar were the priests:
And*p Azariah the son of Nathan was over the officers: and Zabud the son of Nathan was principal officer, and the king's friend:
And*p Ahishar was over the household: and Adoniram the son of Abda was over the tribute.
And*p Solomon had twelve officers over all Israel, which provided victuals for the king and his household: each man his month in a year made provision.
And*p these are their names: The son of Hur, in mount Ephraim:
The*p son of Dekar, in Makaz, and in Shaalbim, and Beth–shemesh, and Elon–beth–hanan:
The*p son of Hesed, in Aruboth; to him pertained Soco, and all the land of Hepher:
The*p son of Abinadab, in all the region of Dor; which had Taphath the daughter of Solomon to wife:
Baana*p the son of Ahilud; to him pertained Taanach and Megiddo, and all Beth–shean, which is by Zarethan beneath Jezreel, from Beth–shean to Abel–meholah, even unto the place that is beyond Jokmeam:

The*p son of Geber, in Ramoth–gilead; to him pertained the towns of Jair the son of Manasseh, which are in Gilead; to him also pertained the region of Argob, which is in Bashan, threescore great cities with walls and brasen bars:
Ahinadab*p the son of Iddo had Mahanaim:
Ahimaaz*p was in Naphtali; he also took Basmath the daughter of Solomon to wife:
Baanah*p the son of Hushai was in Asher and in Aloth:
Jehoshaphat*p the son of Paruah, in Issachar:
Shimei*p the son of Elah, in Benjamin:
Geber*p the son of Uri was in the country of Gilead, in the country of Sihon king of the Amorites, and of Og king of Bashan; and he was the only officer which was in the land.
Judah*p and Israel were many, as the sand which is by the sea in multitude, eating and drinking, and making merry.
And*p Solomon reigned over all kingdoms from the river unto the land of the Philistines, and unto the border of Egypt: they brought presents, and served Solomon all the days of his life.
And*p Solomon's provision for one day was thirty measures of fine flour, and threescore measures of meal,
Ten*p fat oxen, and twenty oxen out of the pastures, and an hundred sheep, beside harts, and roebucks, and fallowdeer, and fatted fowl.
For*p he had dominion over all the region on this side the river, from Tiphsah even to Gaza, over all the kings on this side the river: and he had peace on all sides round about him.
And*p Judah and Israel dwelt safely, every man under his vine and under his fig tree, from Dan even to Beer–sheba, all the days of Solomon.
And*p Solomon had forty thousand stalls of horses for his chariots, and twelve thousand horsemen.
And*p those officers provided victual for king Solomon, and for all that came unto king Solomon's table, every man in his month: they lacked nothing.
Barley*p also and straw for the horses and dromedaries brought they unto the place where the officers were, every man according to his charge.
And*p God gave Solomon wisdom and understanding exceeding much, and largeness of heart, even as the sand that is on the sea shore.
And*p Solomon's wisdom excelled the wisdom of all the children of the east country, and all the wisdom of Egypt.
For*p he was wiser than all men; than Ethan the Ezrahite, and Heman, and Chalcol, and Darda, the sons of Mahol: and his fame was in all nations round about.
And*p he spake three thousand proverbs: and his songs were a thousand and five.
And*p he spake of trees, from the cedar tree that is in Lebanon even unto the hyssop that springeth out of the wall: he spake also of beasts, and of fowl, and of creeping things, and of fishes.
And*p there came of all people to hear the wisdom of Solomon, from all kings of the earth, which had heard of his wisdom.
1 Kings 5
And*p Hiram king of Tyre sent his servants unto Solomon; for he had heard that they had anointed him king in the room of his father: for Hiram was ever a lover of David.
And*p Solomon sent to Hiram, saying,

Thou*p knowest how that David my father could not build an house unto the name of the Lord*s his God for the wars which were about him on every side, until the Lord*s put them under the soles of his feet.
But*p now the Lord*s my God hath given me rest on every side, so that there is neither adversary nor evil occurrent.

And,*p behold, I purpose to build an house unto the name of the Lord*s my God, as the Lord*s spake unto David my father, saying, Thy son, whom I will set upon thy throne in thy room, he shall build an house unto my name.

Now*p therefore command thou that they hew me cedar trees out of Lebanon; and my servants shall be with thy servants: and unto thee will I give hire for thy servants according to all that thou shalt appoint: for thou knowest that there is not among us any that can skill to hew timber like unto the Sidonians.
And*p it came to pass, when Hiram heard the words of Solomon, that he rejoiced greatly, and said, Blessed be the Lord*s this day, which hath given unto David a wise son over this great people.
And*p Hiram sent to Solomon, saying, I have considered the things which thou sentest to me for: and I will do all thy desire concerning timber of cedar, and concerning timber of fir.

My*p servants shall bring them down from Lebanon unto the sea: and I will convey them by sea in floats unto the place that thou shalt appoint me, and will cause them to be discharged there, and thou shalt receive them: and thou shalt accomplish my desire, in giving food for my household.
So*p Hiram gave Solomon cedar trees and fir trees according to all his desire.
And*p Solomon gave Hiram twenty thousand measures of wheat for food to his household, and twenty measures of pure oil: thus gave Solomon to Hiram year by year.
And*p the Lord*s gave Solomon wisdom, as he promised him: and there was peace between Hiram and Solomon; and they two made a league together.
And*p king Solomon raised a levy out of all Israel; and the levy was thirty thousand men.
And*p he sent them to Lebanon, ten thousand a month by courses: a month they were in Lebanon, and two months at home: and Adoniram was over the levy.
And*p Solomon had threescore and ten thousand that bare burdens, and fourscore thousand hewers in the mountains;
Beside*p the chief of Solomon's officers which were over the work, three thousand and three hundred, which ruled over the people that wrought in the work.
And*p the king commanded, and they brought great stones, costly stones, and hewed stones, to lay the foundation of the house.
And*p Solomon's builders and Hiram's builders did hew them, and the stonesquarers: so they prepared timber and stones to build the house.
1 Kings 6

And*p it came to pass in the four hundred and eightieth year after the children of Israel were come out of the land of Egypt, in the fourth year of Solomon's reign over Israel, in the month Zif, which is the second month, that he began to build the house of the Lord.*s
And*p the house which king Solomon built for the Lord,*s the length thereof was threescore cubits, and the breadth thereof twenty cubits, and the height thereof thirty cubits.
And*p the porch before the temple of the house, twenty cubits was the length thereof, according to the breadth of the house; and ten cubits was the breadth thereof before the house.
And*p for the house he made windows of narrow lights.
And*p against the wall of the house he built chambers round about, against the walls of the house round about, both of the temple and of the oracle: and he made chambers round about:

The*p nethermost chamber was five cubits broad, and the middle was six cubits broad, and the third was seven cubits broad: for without in the wall of the house he made narrowed rests round about, that the beams should not be fastened in the walls of the house.

And*p the house, when it was in building, was built of stone made ready before it was brought thither: so that there was neither hammer nor axe nor any tool of iron heard in the house, while it was in building.
The*p door for the middle chamber was in the right side of the house: and they went up with winding stairs into the middle chamber, and out of the middle into the third.
So*p he built the house, and finished it; and covered the house with beams and boards of cedar.
And*p then he built chambers against all the house, five cubits high: and they rested on the house with timber of cedar.
And*p the word of the Lord*s came to Solomon, saying,

Concerning*p this house which thou art in building, if thou wilt walk in my statutes, and execute my judgments, and keep all my commandments to walk in them; then will I perform my word with thee, which I spake unto David thy father:
And*p I will dwell among the children of Israel, and will not forsake my people Israel.
So*p Solomon built the house, and finished it.

And*p he built the walls of the house within with boards of cedar, both the floor of the house, and the walls of the ceiling: and he covered them on the inside with wood, and covered the floor of the house with planks of fir.
And*p he built twenty cubits on the sides of the house, both the floor and the walls with boards of cedar: he even built them for it within, even for the oracle, even for the most holy place.
And*p the house, that is, the temple before it, was forty cubits long.
And*p the cedar of the house within was carved with knops and open flowers: all was cedar; there was no stone seen.
And*p the oracle he prepared in the house within, to set there the ark of the covenant of the Lord.*s

And*p the oracle in the forepart was twenty cubits in length, and twenty cubits in breadth, and twenty cubits in the height thereof: and he overlaid it with pure gold; and so covered the altar which was of cedar.
So*p Solomon overlaid the house within with pure gold: and he made a partition by the chains of gold before the oracle; and he overlaid it with gold.
And*p the whole house he overlaid with gold, until he had finished all the house: also the whole altar that was by the oracle he overlaid with gold.
And*p within the oracle he made two cherubims of olive tree, each ten cubits high.
And*p five cubits was the one wing of the cherub, and five cubits the other wing of the cherub: from the uttermost part of the one wing unto the uttermost part of the other were ten cubits.
And*p the other cherub was ten cubits: both the cherubims were of one measure and one size.
The*p height of the one cherub was ten cubits, and so was it of the other cherub.

And*p he set the cherubims within the inner house: and they stretched forth the wings of the cherubims, so that the wing of the one touched the one wall, and the wing of the other cherub touched the other wall; and their wings touched one another in the midst of the house.
And*p he overlaid the cherubims with gold.
And*p he carved all the walls of the house round about with carved figures of cherubims and palm trees and open flowers, within and without.
And*p the floor of the house he overlaid with gold, within and without.
And*p for the entering of the oracle he made doors of olive tree: the lintel and side posts were a fifth part of the wall.

The*p two doors also were of olive tree; and he carved upon them carvings of cherubims and palm trees and open flowers, and overlaid them with gold, and spread gold upon the cherubims, and upon the palm trees.
So*p also made he for the door of the temple posts of olive tree, a fourth part of the wall.
And*p the two doors were of fir tree: the two leaves of the one door were folding, and the two leaves of the other door were folding.
And*p he carved thereon cherubims and palm trees and open flowers: and covered them with gold fitted upon the carved work.
And*p he built the inner court with three rows of hewed stone, and a row of cedar beams.
In*p the fourth year was the foundation of the house of the Lord*s laid, in the month Zif:

And*p in the eleventh year, in the month Bul, which is the eighth month, was the house finished throughout all the parts thereof, and according to all the fashion of it. So was he seven years in building it.
1 Kings 7
But*p Solomon was building his own house thirteen years, and he finished all his house.

He*p built also the house of the forest of Lebanon; the length thereof was an hundred cubits, and the breadth thereof fifty cubits, and the height thereof thirty cubits, upon four rows of cedar pillars, with cedar beams upon the pillars.
And*p it was covered with cedar above upon the beams, that lay on forty five pillars, fifteen in a row.
And*p there were windows in three rows, and light was against light in three ranks.
And*p all the doors and posts were square, with the windows: and light was against light in three ranks.
And*p he made a porch of pillars; the length thereof was fifty cubits, and the breadth thereof thirty cubits: and the porch was before them: and the other pillars and the thick beam were before them.
Then*p he made a porch for the throne where he might judge, even the porch of judgment: and it was covered with cedar from one side of the floor to the other.
And*p his house where he dwelt had another court within the porch, which was of the like work. Solomon made also an house for Pharaoh's daughter, whom he had taken to wife, like unto this porch.

All*p these were of costly stones, according to the measures of hewed stones, sawed with saws, within and without, even from the foundation unto the coping, and so on the outside toward the great court.
And*p the foundation was of costly stones, even great stones, stones of ten cubits, and stones of eight cubits.
And*p above were costly stones, after the measures of hewed stones, and cedars.
And*p the great court round about was with three rows of hewed stones, and a row of cedar beams, both for the inner court of the house of the Lord,*s and for the porch of the house.
And*p king Solomon sent and fetched Hiram out of Tyre.

He*p was a widow's son of the tribe of Naphtali, and his father was a man of Tyre, a worker in brass: and he was filled with wisdom, and understanding, and cunning to work all works in brass. And he came to king Solomon, and wrought all his work.
For*p he cast two pillars of brass, of eighteen cubits high apiece: and a line of twelve cubits did compass either of them about.
And*p he made two chapiters of molten brass, to set upon the tops of the pillars: the height of the one chapiter was five cubits, and the height of the other chapiter was five cubits:
And*p nets of checker work, and wreaths of chain work, for the chapiters which were upon the top of the pillars; seven for the one chapiter, and seven for the other chapiter.
And*p he made the pillars, and two rows round about upon the one network, to cover the chapiters that were upon the top, with pomegranates: and so did he for the other chapiter.
And*p the chapiters that were upon the top of the pillars were of lily work in the porch, four cubits.

And*p the chapiters upon the two pillars had pomegranates also above, over against the belly which was by the network: and the pomegranates were two hundred in rows round about upon the other chapiter.
And*p he set up the pillars in the porch of the temple: and he set up the right pillar, and called the name thereof Jachin: and he set up the left pillar, and called the name thereof Boaz.
And*p upon the top of the pillars was lily work: so was the work of the pillars finished.
And*p he made a molten sea, ten cubits from the one brim to the other: it was round all about, and his height was five cubits: and a line of thirty cubits did compass it round about.
And*p under the brim of it round about there were knops compassing it, ten in a cubit, compassing the sea round about: the knops were cast in two rows, when it was cast.

It*p stood upon twelve oxen, three looking toward the north, and three looking toward the west, and three looking toward the south, and three looking toward the east: and the sea was set above upon them, and all their hinder parts were inward.
And*p it was an hand breadth thick, and the brim thereof was wrought like the brim of a cup, with flowers of lilies: it contained two thousand baths.
And*p he made ten bases of brass; four cubits was the length of one base, and four cubits the breadth thereof, and three cubits the height of it.
And*p the work of the bases was on this manner: they had borders, and the borders were between the ledges:
And*p on the borders that were between the ledges were lions, oxen, and cherubims: and upon the ledges there was a base above: and beneath the lions and oxen were certain additions made of thin work.
And*p every base had four brasen wheels, and plates of brass: and the four corners thereof had undersetters: under the laver were undersetters molten, at the side of every addition.

And*p the mouth of it within the chapiter and above was a cubit: but the mouth thereof was round after the work of the base, a cubit and an half: and also upon the mouth of it were gravings with their borders, foursquare, not round.
And*p under the borders were four wheels; and the axletrees of the wheels were joined to the base: and the height of a wheel was a cubit and half a cubit.
And*p the work of the wheels was like the work of a chariot wheel: their axletrees, and their naves, and their felloes, and their spokes, were all molten.
And*p there were four undersetters to the four corners of one base: and the undersetters were of the very base itself.
And*p in the top of the base was there a round compass of half a cubit high: and on the top of the base the ledges thereof and the borders thereof were of the same.
For*p on the plates of the ledges thereof, and on the borders thereof, he graved cherubims, lions, and palm trees, according to the proportion of every one, and additions round about.
After*p this manner he made the ten bases: all of them had one casting, one measure, and one size.
Then*p made he ten lavers of brass: one laver contained forty baths: and every laver was four cubits: and upon every one of the ten bases one laver.
And*p he put five bases on the right side of the house, and five on the left side of the house: and he set the sea on the right side of the house eastward over against the south.
And*p Hiram made the lavers, and the shovels, and the basins. So Hiram made an end of doing all the work that he made king Solomon for the house of the Lord:*s
The*p two pillars, and the two bowls of the chapiters that were on the top of the two pillars; and the two networks, to cover the two bowls of the chapiters which were upon the top of the pillars;
And*p four hundred pomegranates for the two networks, even two rows of pomegranates for one network, to cover the two bowls of the chapiters that were upon the pillars;
And*p the ten bases, and ten lavers on the bases;
And*p one sea, and twelve oxen under the sea;
And*p the pots, and the shovels, and the basins: and all these vessels, which Hiram made to king Solomon for the house of the Lord,*s were of bright brass.
In*p the plain of Jordan did the king cast them, in the clay ground between Succoth and Zarethan.
And*p Solomon left all the vessels unweighed, because they were exceeding many: neither was the weight of the brass found out.
And*p Solomon made all the vessels that pertained unto the house of the Lord:*s the altar of gold, and the table of gold, whereupon the shewbread was,
And*p the candlesticks of pure gold, five on the right side, and five on the left, before the oracle, with the flowers, and the lamps, and the tongs of gold,

And*p the bowls, and the snuffers, and the basins, and the spoons, and the censers of pure gold; and the hinges of gold, both for the doors of the inner house, the most holy place, and for the doors of the house, to wit, of the temple.

So*p was ended all the work that king Solomon made for the house of the Lord.*s And Solomon brought in the things which David his father had dedicated; even the silver, and the gold, and the vessels, did he put among the treasures of the house of the Lord.*s
1 Kings 8

Then*p Solomon assembled the elders of Israel, and all the heads of the tribes, the chief of the fathers of the children of Israel, unto king Solomon in Jerusalem, that they might bring up the ark of the covenant of the Lord*s out of the city of David, which is Zion.
And*p all the men of Israel assembled themselves unto king Solomon at the feast in the month Ethanim, which is the seventh month.
And*p all the elders of Israel came, and the priests took up the ark.
And*p they brought up the ark of the Lord,*s and the tabernacle of the congregation, and all the holy vessels that were in the tabernacle, even those did the priests and the Levites bring up.
And*p king Solomon, and all the congregation of Israel, that were assembled unto him, were with him before the ark, sacrificing sheep and oxen, that could not be told nor numbered for multitude.
And*p the priests brought in the ark of the covenant of the Lord*s unto his place, into the oracle of the house, to the most holy place, even under the wings of the cherubims.
For*p the cherubims spread forth their two wings over the place of the ark, and the cherubims covered the ark and the staves thereof above.
And*p they drew out the staves, that the ends of the staves were seen out in the holy place before the oracle, and they were not seen without: and there they are unto this day.
There*p was nothing in the ark save the two tables of stone, which Moses put there at Horeb, when the Lord*s made a covenant with the children of Israel, when they came out of the land of Egypt.
And*p it came to pass, when the priests were come out of the holy place, that the cloud filled the house of the Lord,*s
So*p that the priests could not stand to minister because of the cloud: for the glory of the Lord*s had filled the house of the Lord.*s
Then*p spake Solomon, The Lord*s said that he would dwell in the thick darkness.
I*p have surely built thee an house to dwell in, a settled place for thee to abide in for ever.
And*p the king turned his face about, and blessed all the congregation of Israel: (and all the congregation of Israel stood;)
And*p he said, Blessed be the Lord*s God of Israel, which spake with his mouth unto David my father, and hath with his hand fulfilled it, saying,

Since*p the day that I brought forth my people Israel out of Egypt, I chose no city out of all the tribes of Israel to build an house, that my name might be therein; but I chose David to be over my people Israel.
And*p it was in the heart of David my father to build an house for the name of the Lord*s God of Israel.
And*p the Lord*s said unto David my father, Whereas it was in thine heart to build an house unto my name, thou didst well that it was in thine heart.
Nevertheless*p thou shalt not build the house; but thy son that shall come forth out of thy loins, he shall build the house unto my name.

And*p the Lord*s hath performed his word that he spake, and I am risen up in the room of David my father, and sit on the throne of Israel, as the Lord*s promised, and have built an house for the name of the Lord*s God of Israel.
And*p I have set there a place for the ark, wherein is the covenant of the Lord,*s which he made with our fathers, when he brought them out of the land of Egypt.
And*p Solomon stood before the altar of the Lord*s in the presence of all the congregation of Israel, and spread forth his hands toward heaven:
And*p he said, Lord*s God of Israel, there is no God like thee, in heaven above, or on earth beneath, who keepest covenant and mercy with thy servants that walk before thee with all their heart:
Who*p hast kept with thy servant David my father that thou promisedst him: thou spakest also with thy mouth, and hast fulfilled it with thine hand, as it is this day.

Therefore*p now, Lord*s God of Israel, keep with thy servant David my father that thou promisedst him, saying, There shall not fail thee a man in my sight to sit on the throne of Israel; so that thy children take heed to their way, that they walk before me as thou hast walked before me.
And*p now, O God of Israel, let thy word, I pray thee, be verified, which thou spakest unto thy servant David my father.
But*p will God indeed dwell on the earth? behold, the heaven and heaven of heavens cannot contain thee; how much less this house that I have builded?
Yet*p have thou respect unto the prayer of thy servant, and to his supplication, O Lord*s my God, to hearken unto the cry and to the prayer, which thy servant prayeth before thee to day:

That*p thine eyes may be open toward this house night and day, even toward the place of which thou hast said, My name shall be there: that thou mayest hearken unto the prayer which thy servant shall make toward this place.
And*p hearken thou to the supplication of thy servant, and of thy people Israel, when they shall pray toward this place: and hear thou in heaven thy dwelling place: and when thou hearest, forgive.
If*p any man trespass against his neighbour, and an oath be laid upon him to cause him to swear, and the oath come before thine altar in this house:
Then*p hear thou in heaven, and do, and judge thy servants, condemning the wicked, to bring his way upon his head; and justifying the righteous, to give him according to his righteousness.

When*p thy people Israel be smitten down before the enemy, because they have sinned against thee, and shall turn again to thee, and confess thy name, and pray, and make supplication unto thee in this house:
Then*p hear thou in heaven, and forgive the sin of thy people Israel, and bring them again unto the land which thou gavest unto their fathers.
When*p heaven is shut up, and there is no rain, because they have sinned against thee; if they pray toward this place, and confess thy name, and turn from their sin, when thou afflictest them:

Then*p hear thou in heaven, and forgive the sin of thy servants, and of thy people Israel, that thou teach them the good way wherein they should walk, and give rain upon thy land, which thou hast given to thy people for an inheritance.

If*p there be in the land famine, if there be pestilence, blasting, mildew, locust, or if there be caterpiller; if their enemy besiege them in the land of their cities; whatsoever plague, whatsoever sickness there be;
What*p prayer and supplication soever be made by any man, or by all thy people Israel, which shall know every man the plague of his own heart, and spread forth his hands toward this house:

Then*p hear thou in heaven thy dwelling place, and forgive, and do, and give to every man according to his ways, whose heart thou knowest; (for thou, even thou only, knowest the hearts of all the children of men;)
That*p they may fear thee all the days that they live in the land which thou gavest unto our fathers.
Moreover*p concerning a stranger, that is not of thy people Israel, but cometh out of a far country for thy name's sake;
(For*p they shall hear of thy great name, and of thy strong hand, and of thy stretched out arm;) when he shall come and pray toward this house;

Hear*p thou in heaven thy dwelling place, and do according to all that the stranger calleth to thee for: that all people of the earth may know thy name, to fear thee, as do thy people Israel; and that they may know that this house, which I have builded, is called by thy name.

If*p thy people go out to battle against their enemy, whithersoever thou shalt send them, and shall pray unto the Lord*s toward the city which thou hast chosen, and toward the house that I have built for thy name:
Then*p hear thou in heaven their prayer and their supplication, and maintain their cause.

If*p they sin against thee, (for there is no man that sinneth not,) and thou be angry with them, and deliver them to the enemy, so that they carry them away captives unto the land of the enemy, far or near;

Yet*p if they shall bethink themselves in the land whither they were carried captives, and repent, and make supplication unto thee in the land of them that carried them captives, saying, We have sinned, and have done perversely, we have committed wickedness;

And*p so return unto thee with all their heart, and with all their soul, in the land of their enemies, which led them away captive, and pray unto thee toward their land, which thou gavest unto their fathers, the city which thou hast chosen, and the house which I have built for thy name:
Then*p hear thou their prayer and their supplication in heaven thy dwelling place, and maintain their cause,

And*p forgive thy people that have sinned against thee, and all their transgressions wherein they have transgressed against thee, and give them compassion before them who carried them captive, that they may have compassion on them:
For*p they be thy people, and thine inheritance, which thou broughtest forth out of Egypt, from the midst of the furnace of iron:
That*p thine eyes may be open unto the supplication of thy servant, and unto the supplication of thy people Israel, to hearken unto them in all that they call for unto thee.

For*p thou didst separate them from among all the people of the earth, to be thine inheritance, as thou spakest by the hand of Moses thy servant, when thou broughtest our fathers out of Egypt, O Lord God.*s

And*p it was so, that when Solomon had made an end of praying all this prayer and supplication unto the Lord,*s he arose from before the altar of the Lord,*s from kneeling on his knees with his hands spread up to heaven.
And*p he stood, and blessed all the congregation of Israel with a loud voice, saying,

Blessed*p be the Lord,*s that hath given rest unto his people Israel, according to all that he promised: there hath not failed one word of all his good promise, which he promised by the hand of Moses his servant.
The*p Lord*s our God be with us, as he was with our fathers: let him not leave us, nor forsake us:
That*p he may incline our hearts unto him, to walk in all his ways, and to keep his commandments, and his statutes, and his judgments, which he commanded our fathers.

And*p let these my words, wherewith I have made supplication before the Lord,*s be nigh unto the Lord*s our God day and night, that he maintain the cause of his servant, and the cause of his people Israel at all times, as the matter shall require:
That*p all the people of the earth may know that the Lord*s is God, and that there is none else.
Let*p your heart therefore be perfect with the Lord*s our God, to walk in his statutes, and to keep his commandments, as at this day.
And*p the king, and all Israel with him, offered sacrifice before the Lord.*s

And*p Solomon offered a sacrifice of peace offerings, which he offered unto the Lord,*s two and twenty thousand oxen, and an hundred and twenty thousand sheep. So the king and all the children of Israel dedicated the house of the Lord.*s

The*p same day did the king hallow the middle of the court that was before the house of the Lord:*s for there he offered burnt offerings, and meat offerings, and the fat of the peace offerings: because the brasen altar that was before the Lord*s was too little to receive the burnt offerings, and meat offerings, and the fat of the peace offerings.

And*p at that time Solomon held a feast, and all Israel with him, a great congregation, from the entering in of Hamath unto the river of Egypt, before the Lord*s our God, seven days and seven days, even fourteen days.

On*p the eighth day he sent the people away: and they blessed the king, and went unto their tents joyful and glad of heart for all the goodness that the Lord*s had done for David his servant, and for Israel his people.
1 Kings 9
And*p it came to pass, when Solomon had finished the building of the house of the Lord,*s and the king's house, and all Solomon's desire which he was pleased to do,
That*p the Lord*s appeared to Solomon the second time, as he had appeared unto him at Gibeon.

And*p the Lord*s said unto him, I have heard thy prayer and thy supplication, that thou hast made before me: I have hallowed this house, which thou hast built, to put my name there for ever; and mine eyes and mine heart shall be there perpetually.

And*p if thou wilt walk before me, as David thy father walked, in integrity of heart, and in uprightness, to do according to all that I have commanded thee, and wilt keep my statutes and my judgments:
Then*p I will establish the throne of thy kingdom upon Israel for ever, as I promised to David thy father, saying, There shall not fail thee a man upon the throne of Israel.
But*p if ye shall at all turn from following me, ye or your children, and will not keep my commandments and my statutes which I have set before you, but go and serve other gods, and worship them:

Then*p will I cut off Israel out of the land which I have given them; and this house, which I have hallowed for my name, will I cast out of my sight; and Israel shall be a proverb and a byword among all people:
And*p at this house, which is high, every one that passeth by it shall be astonished, and shall hiss; and they shall say, Why hath the Lord*s done thus unto this land, and to this house?

And*p they shall answer, Because they forsook the Lord*s their God, who brought forth their fathers out of the land of Egypt, and have taken hold upon other gods, and have worshipped them, and served them: therefore hath the Lord*s brought upon them all this evil.
And*p it came to pass at the end of twenty years, when Solomon had built the two houses, the house of the Lord,*s and the king's house,

(Now*p Hiram the king of Tyre had furnished Solomon with cedar trees and fir trees, and with gold, according to all his desire,) that then king Solomon gave Hiram twenty cities in the land of Galilee.
And*p Hiram came out from Tyre to see the cities which Solomon had given him; and they pleased him not.
And*p he said, What cities are these which thou hast given me, my brother? And he called them the land of Cabul unto this day.
And*p Hiram sent to the king sixscore talents of gold.
And*p this is the reason of the levy which king Solomon raised; for to build the house of the Lord,*s and his own house, and Millo, and the wall of Jerusalem, and Hazor, and Megiddo, and Gezer.
For*p Pharaoh king of Egypt had gone up, and taken Gezer, and burnt it with fire, and slain the Canaanites that dwelt in the city, and given it for a present unto his daughter, Solomon's wife.
And*p Solomon built Gezer, and Beth–horon the nether,
And*p Baalath, and Tamar in the wilderness, in the land,

And*p all the cities of store that Solomon had, and cities for his chariots, and cities for his horsemen, and that which Solomon desired to build in Jerusalem, and in Lebanon, and in all the land of his dominion.
And*p all the people that were left of the Amorites, Hittites, Perizzites, Hivites, and Jebusites, which were not of the children of Israel,
Their*p children that were left after them in the land, whom the children of Israel also were not able utterly to destroy, upon those did Solomon levy a tribute of bondservice unto this day.
But*p of the children of Israel did Solomon make no bondmen: but they were men of war, and his servants, and his princes, and his captains, and rulers of his chariots, and his horsemen.
These*p were the chief of the officers that were over Solomon's work, five hundred and fifty, which bare rule over the people that wrought in the work.
But*p Pharaoh's daughter came up out of the city of David unto her house which Solomon had built for her: then did he build Millo.

And*p three times in a year did Solomon offer burnt offerings and peace offerings upon the altar which he built unto the Lord,*s and he burnt incense upon the altar that was before the Lord.*s So he finished the house.
And*p king Solomon made a navy of ships in Ezion–geber, which is beside Eloth, on the shore of the Red sea, in the land of Edom.
And*p Hiram sent in the navy his servants, shipmen that had knowledge of the sea, with the servants of Solomon.
And*p they came to Ophir, and fetched from thence gold, four hundred and twenty talents, and brought it to king Solomon.
1 Kings 10
And*p when the queen of Sheba heard of the fame of Solomon concerning the name of the Lord,*s she came to prove him with hard questions.

And*p she came to Jerusalem with a very great train, with camels that bare spices, and very much gold, and precious stones: and when she was come to Solomon, she communed with him of all that was in her heart.
And*p Solomon told her all her questions: there was not any thing hid from the king, which he told her not.
And*p when the queen of Sheba had seen all Solomon's wisdom, and the house that he had built,

And*p the meat of his table, and the sitting of his servants, and the attendance of his ministers, and their apparel, and his cupbearers, and his ascent by which he went up unto the house of the Lord;*s there was no more spirit in her.
And*p she said to the king, It was a true report that I heard in mine own land of thy acts and of thy wisdom.
Howbeit*p I believed not the words, until I came, and mine eyes had seen it: and, behold, the half was not told me: thy wisdom and prosperity exceedeth the fame which I heard.
Happy*p are thy men, happy are these thy servants, which stand continually before thee, and that hear thy wisdom.
Blessed*p be the Lord*s thy God, which delighted in thee, to set thee on the throne of Israel: because the Lord*s loved Israel for ever, therefore made he thee king, to do judgment and justice.

And*p she gave the king an hundred and twenty talents of gold, and of spices very great store, and precious stones: there came no more such abundance of spices as these which the queen of Sheba gave to king Solomon.
And*p the navy also of Hiram, that brought gold from Ophir, brought in from Ophir great plenty of almug trees, and precious stones.

And*p the king made of the almug trees pillars for the house of the Lord,*s and for the king's house, harps also and psalteries for singers: there came no such almug trees, nor were seen unto this day.

And*p king Solomon gave unto the queen of Sheba all her desire, whatsoever she asked, beside that which Solomon gave her of his royal bounty. So she turned and went to her own country, she and her servants.
Now*p the weight of gold that came to Solomon in one year was six hundred threescore and six talents of gold,
Beside*p that he had of the merchantmen, and of the traffick of the spice merchants, and of all the kings of Arabia, and of the governors of the country.
And*p king Solomon made two hundred targets of beaten gold: six hundred shekels of gold went to one target.
And*p he made three hundred shields of beaten gold; three pound of gold went to one shield: and the king put them in the house of the forest of Lebanon.
Moreover*p the king made a great throne of ivory, and overlaid it with the best gold.
The*p throne had six steps, and the top of the throne was round behind: and there were stays on either side on the place of the seat, and two lions stood beside the stays.
And*p twelve lions stood there on the one side and on the other upon the six steps: there was not the like made in any kingdom.

And*p all king Solomon's drinking vessels were of gold, and all the vessels of the house of the forest of Lebanon were of pure gold; none were of silver: it was nothing accounted of in the days of Solomon.
For*p the king had at sea a navy of Tarshish with the navy of Hiram: once in three years came the navy of Tarshish, bringing gold, and silver, ivory, and apes, and peacocks.
So*p king Solomon exceeded all the kings of the earth for riches and for wisdom.
And*p all the earth sought to Solomon, to hear his wisdom, which God had put in his heart.
And*p they brought every man his present, vessels of silver, and vessels of gold, and garments, and armour, and spices, horses, and mules, a rate year by year.

And*p Solomon gathered together chariots and horsemen: and he had a thousand and four hundred chariots, and twelve thousand horsemen, whom he bestowed in the cities for chariots, and with the king at Jerusalem.
And*p the king made silver to be in Jerusalem as stones, and cedars made he to be as the sycomore trees that are in the vale, for abundance.
And*p Solomon had horses brought out of Egypt, and linen yarn: the king's merchants received the linen yarn at a price.

And*p a chariot came up and went out of Egypt for six hundred shekels of silver, and an horse for an hundred and fifty: and so for all the kings of the Hittites, and for the kings of Syria, did they bring them out by their means.
1 Kings 11
But*p king Solomon loved many strange women, together with the daughter of Pharaoh, women of the Moabites, Ammonites, Edomites, Zidonians, and Hittites;

Of*p the nations concerning which the Lord*s said unto the children of Israel, Ye shall not go in to them, neither shall they come in unto you: for surely they will turn away your heart after their gods: Solomon clave unto these in love.
And*p he had seven hundred wives, princesses, and three hundred concubines: and his wives turned away his heart.
For*p it came to pass, when Solomon was old, that his wives turned away his heart after other gods: and his heart was not perfect with the Lord*s his God, as was the heart of David his father.
For*p Solomon went after Ashtoreth the goddess of the Zidonians, and after Milcom the abomination of the Ammonites.
And*p Solomon did evil in the sight of the Lord,*s and went not fully after the Lord,*s as did David his father.
Then*p did Solomon build an high place for Chemosh, the abomination of Moab, in the hill that is before Jerusalem, and for Molech, the abomination of the children of Ammon.
And*p likewise did he for all his strange wives, which burnt incense and sacrificed unto their gods.
And*p the Lord*s was angry with Solomon, because his heart was turned from the Lord*s God of Israel, which had appeared unto him twice,
And*p had commanded him concerning this thing, that he should not go after other gods: but he kept not that which the Lord*s commanded.

Wherefore*p the Lord*s said unto Solomon, Forasmuch as this is done of thee, and thou hast not kept my covenant and my statutes, which I have commanded thee, I will surely rend the kingdom from thee, and will give it to thy servant.
Notwithstanding*p in thy days I will not do it for David thy father's sake: but I will rend it out of the hand of thy son.
Howbeit*p I will not rend away all the kingdom; but will give one tribe to thy son for David my servant's sake, and for Jerusalem's sake which I have chosen.
And*p the Lord*s stirred up an adversary unto Solomon, Hadad the Edomite: he was of the king's seed in Edom.
For*p it came to pass, when David was in Edom, and Joab the captain of the host was gone up to bury the slain, after he had smitten every male in Edom;
(For*p six months did Joab remain there with all Israel, until he had cut off every male in Edom:)
That*p Hadad fled, he and certain Edomites of his father's servants with him, to go into Egypt; Hadad being yet a little child.

And*p they arose out of Midian, and came to Paran: and they took men with them out of Paran, and they came to Egypt, unto Pharaoh king of Egypt; which gave him an house, and appointed him victuals, and gave him land.
And*p Hadad found great favour in the sight of Pharaoh, so that he gave him to wife the sister of his own wife, the sister of Tahpenes the queen.
And*p the sister of Tahpenes bare him Genubath his son, whom Tahpenes weaned in Pharaoh's house: and Genubath was in Pharaoh's household among the sons of Pharaoh.
And*p when Hadad heard in Egypt that David slept with his fathers, and that Joab the captain of the host was dead, Hadad said to Pharaoh, Let me depart, that I may go to mine own country.
Then*p Pharaoh said unto him, But what hast thou lacked with me, that, behold, thou seekest to go to thine own country? And he answered, Nothing: howbeit let me go in any wise.
And*p God stirred him up another adversary, Rezon the son of Eliadah, which fled from his lord Hadadezer king of Zobah:
And*p he gathered men unto him, and became captain over a band, when David slew them of Zobah: and they went to Damascus, and dwelt therein, and reigned in Damascus.
And*p he was an adversary to Israel all the days of Solomon, beside the mischief that Hadad did: and he abhorred Israel, and reigned over Syria.
And*p Jeroboam the son of Nebat, an Ephrathite of Zeredah, Solomon's servant, whose mother's name was Zeruah, a widow woman, even he lifted up his hand against the king.
And*p this was the cause that he lifted up his hand against the king: Solomon built Millo, and repaired the breaches of the city of David his father.
And*p the man Jeroboam was a mighty man of valour: and Solomon seeing the young man that he was industrious, he made him ruler over all the charge of the house of Joseph.

And*p it came to pass at that time when Jeroboam went out of Jerusalem, that the prophet Ahijah the Shilonite found him in the way; and he had clad himself with a new garment; and they two were alone in the field:
And*p Ahijah caught the new garment that was on him, and rent it in twelve pieces:
And*p he said to Jeroboam, Take thee ten pieces: for thus saith the Lord,*s the God of Israel, Behold, I will rend the kingdom out of the hand of Solomon, and will give ten tribes to thee:
(But*p he shall have one tribe for my servant David's sake, and for Jerusalem's sake, the city which I have chosen out of all the tribes of Israel:)

Because*p that they have forsaken me, and have worshipped Ashtoreth the goddess of the Zidonians, Chemosh the god of the Moabites, and Milcom the god of the children of Ammon, and have not walked in my ways, to do that which is right in mine eyes, and to keep my statutes and my judgments, as did David his father.

Howbeit*p I will not take the whole kingdom out of his hand: but I will make him prince all the days of his life for David my servant's sake, whom I chose, because he kept my commandments and my statutes:
But*p I will take the kingdom out of his son's hand, and will give it unto thee, even ten tribes.
And*p unto his son will I give one tribe, that David my servant may have a light alway before me in Jerusalem, the city which I have chosen me to put my name there.
And*p I will take thee, and thou shalt reign according to all that thy soul desireth, and shalt be king over Israel.

And*p it shall be, if thou wilt hearken unto all that I command thee, and wilt walk in my ways, and do that is right in my sight, to keep my statutes and my commandments, as David my servant did; that I will be with thee, and build thee a sure house, as I built for David, and will give Israel unto thee.
And*p I will for this afflict the seed of David, but not for ever.
Solomon*p sought therefore to kill Jeroboam. And Jeroboam arose, and fled into Egypt, unto Shishak king of Egypt, and was in Egypt until the death of Solomon.
And*p the rest of the acts of Solomon, and all that he did, and his wisdom, are they not written in the book of the acts of Solomon?
And*p the time that Solomon reigned in Jerusalem over all Israel was forty years.
And*p Solomon slept with his fathers, and was buried in the city of David his father: and Rehoboam his son reigned in his stead.
1 Kings 12
And*p Rehoboam went to Shechem: for all Israel were come to Shechem to make him king.
And*p it came to pass, when Jeroboam the son of Nebat, who was yet in Egypt, heard of it, (for he was fled from the presence of king Solomon, and Jeroboam dwelt in Egypt;)
That*p they sent and called him. And Jeroboam and all the congregation of Israel came, and spake unto Rehoboam, saying,
Thy*p father made our yoke grievous: now therefore make thou the grievous service of thy father, and his heavy yoke which he put upon us, lighter, and we will serve thee.
And*p he said unto them, Depart yet for three days, then come again to me. And the people departed.
And*p king Rehoboam consulted with the old men, that stood before Solomon his father while he yet lived, and said, How do ye advise that I may answer this people?
And*p they spake unto him, saying, If thou wilt be a servant unto this people this day, and wilt serve them, and answer them, and speak good words to them, then they will be thy servants for ever.
But*p he forsook the counsel of the old men, which they had given him, and consulted with the young men that were grown up with him, and which stood before him:
And*p he said unto them, What counsel give ye that we may answer this people, who have spoken to me, saying, Make the yoke which thy father did put upon us lighter?

And*p the young men that were grown up with him spake unto him, saying, Thus shalt thou speak unto this people that spake unto thee, saying, Thy father made our yoke heavy, but make thou it lighter unto us; thus shalt thou say unto them, My little finger shall be thicker than my father's loins.
And*p now whereas my father did lade you with a heavy yoke, I will add to your yoke: my father hath chastised you with whips, but I will chastise you with scorpions.
So*p Jeroboam and all the people came to Rehoboam the third day, as the king had appointed, saying, Come to me again the third day.
And*p the king answered the people roughly, and forsook the old men's counsel that they gave him;

And*p spake to them after the counsel of the young men, saying, My father made your yoke heavy, and I will add to your yoke: my father also chastised you with whips, but I will chastise you with scorpions.
Wherefore*p the king hearkened not unto the people; for the cause was from the Lord,*s that he might perform his saying, which the Lord*s spake by Ahijah the Shilonite unto Jeroboam the son of Nebat.

So*p when all Israel saw that the king hearkened not unto them, the people answered the king, saying, What portion have we in David? neither have we inheritance in the son of Jesse: to your tents, O Israel: now see to thine own house, David. So Israel departed unto their tents.
But*p as for the children of Israel which dwelt in the cities of Judah, Rehoboam reigned over them.
Then*p king Rehoboam sent Adoram, who was over the tribute; and all Israel stoned him with stones, that he died. Therefore king Rehoboam made speed to get him up to his chariot, to flee to Jerusalem.
So*p Israel rebelled against the house of David unto this day.

And*p it came to pass, when all Israel heard that Jeroboam was come again, that they sent and called him unto the congregation, and made him king over all Israel: there was none that followed the house of David, but the tribe of Judah only.

And*p when Rehoboam was come to Jerusalem, he assembled all the house of Judah, with the tribe of Benjamin, an hundred and fourscore thousand chosen men, which were warriors, to fight against the house of Israel, to bring the kingdom again to Rehoboam the son of Solomon.
But*p the word of God came unto Shemaiah the man of God, saying,
Speak*p unto Rehoboam, the son of Solomon, king of Judah, and unto all the house of Judah and Benjamin, and to the remnant of the people, saying,

Thus*p saith the Lord,*s Ye shall not go up, nor fight against your brethren the children of Israel: return every man to his house; for this thing is from me. They hearkened therefore to the word of the Lord,*s and returned to depart, according to the word of the Lord.*s
Then*p Jeroboam built Shechem in mount Ephraim, and dwelt therein; and went out from thence, and built Penuel.
And*p Jeroboam said in his heart, Now shall the kingdom return to the house of David:

If*p this people go up to do sacrifice in the house of the Lord*s at Jerusalem, then shall the heart of this people turn again unto their lord, even unto Rehoboam king of Judah, and they shall kill me, and go again to Rehoboam king of Judah.

Whereupon*p the king took counsel, and made two calves of gold, and said unto them, It is too much for you to go up to Jerusalem: behold thy gods, O Israel, which brought thee up out of the land of Egypt.
And*p he set the one in Beth–el, and the other put he in Dan.
And*p this thing became a sin: for the people went to worship before the one, even unto Dan.
And*p he made an house of high places, and made priests of the lowest of the people, which were not of the sons of Levi.

And*p Jeroboam ordained a feast in the eighth month, on the fifteenth day of the month, like unto the feast that is in Judah, and he offered upon the altar. So did he in Beth–el, sacrificing unto the calves that he had made: and he placed in Beth–el the priests of the high places which he had made.

So*p he offered upon the altar which he had made in Beth–el the fifteenth day of the eighth month, even in the month which he had devised of his own heart; and ordained a feast unto the children of Israel: and he offered upon the altar, and burnt incense.
1 Kings 13
And,*p behold, there came a man of God out of Judah by the word of the Lord*s unto Beth–el: and Jeroboam stood by the altar to burn incense.

And*p he cried against the altar in the word of the Lord,*s and said, O altar, altar, thus saith the Lord;*s Behold, a child shall be born unto the house of David, Josiah by name; and upon thee shall he offer the priests of the high places that burn incense upon thee, and men's bones shall be burnt upon thee.
And*p he gave a sign the same day, saying, This is the sign which the Lord*s hath spoken; Behold, the altar shall be rent, and the ashes that are upon it shall be poured out.

And*p it came to pass, when king Jeroboam heard the saying of the man of God, which had cried against the altar in Beth–el, that he put forth his hand from the altar, saying, Lay hold on him. And his hand, which he put forth against him, dried up, so that he could not pull it in again to him.
The*p altar also was rent, and the ashes poured out from the altar, according to the sign which the man of God had given by the word of the Lord.*s

And*p the king answered and said unto the man of God, Entreat now the face of the Lord*s thy God, and pray for me, that my hand may be restored me again. And the man of God besought the Lord,*s and the king's hand was restored him again, and became as it was before.
And*p the king said unto the man of God, Come home with me, and refresh thyself, and I will give thee a reward.
And*p the man of God said unto the king, If thou wilt give me half thine house, I will not go in with thee, neither will I eat bread nor drink water in this place:
For*p so was it charged me by the word of the Lord,*s saying, Eat no bread, nor drink water, nor turn again by the same way that thou camest.
So*p he went another way, and returned not by the way that he came to Beth–el.

Now*p there dwelt an old prophet in Beth–el; and his sons came and told him all the works that the man of God had done that day in Beth–el: the words which he had spoken unto the king, them they told also to their father.
And*p their father said unto them, What way went he? For his sons had seen what way the man of God went, which came from Judah.
And*p he said unto his sons, Saddle me the ass. So they saddled him the ass: and he rode thereon,
And*p went after the man of God, and found him sitting under an oak: and he said unto him, Art thou the man of God that camest from Judah? And he said, I am.
Then*p he said unto him, Come home with me, and eat bread.
And*p he said, I may not return with thee, nor go in with thee: neither will I eat bread nor drink water with thee in this place:
For*p it was said to me by the word of the Lord,*s Thou shalt eat no bread nor drink water there, nor turn again to go by the way that thou camest.

He*p said unto him, I am a prophet also as thou art; and an angel spake unto me by the word of the Lord,*s saying, Bring him back with thee into thine house, that he may eat bread and drink water. But he lied unto him.
So*p he went back with him, and did eat bread in his house, and drank water.
And*p it came to pass, as they sat at the table, that the word of the Lord*s came unto the prophet that brought him back:

And*p he cried unto the man of God that came from Judah, saying, Thus saith the Lord,*s Forasmuch as thou hast disobeyed the mouth of the Lord,*s and hast not kept the commandment which the Lord*s thy God commanded thee,

But*p camest back, and hast eaten bread and drunk water in the place, of the which the Lord*s did say to thee, Eat no bread, and drink no water; thy carcase shall not come unto the sepulchre of thy fathers.
And*p it came to pass, after he had eaten bread, and after he had drunk, that he saddled for him the ass, to wit, for the prophet whom he had brought back.
And*p when he was gone, a lion met him by the way, and slew him: and his carcase was cast in the way, and the ass stood by it, the lion also stood by the carcase.
And,*p behold, men passed by, and saw the carcase cast in the way, and the lion standing by the carcase: and they came and told it in the city where the old prophet dwelt.

And*p when the prophet that brought him back from the way heard thereof, he said, It is the man of God, who was disobedient unto the word of the Lord:*s therefore the Lord*s hath delivered him unto the lion, which hath torn him, and slain him, according to the word of the Lord,*s which he spake unto him.
And*p he spake to his sons, saying, Saddle me the ass. And they saddled him.
And*p he went and found his carcase cast in the way, and the ass and the lion standing by the carcase: the lion had not eaten the carcase, nor torn the ass.
And*p the prophet took up the carcase of the man of God, and laid it upon the ass, and brought it back: and the old prophet came to the city, to mourn and to bury him.
And*p he laid his carcase in his own grave; and they mourned over him, saying, Alas, my brother!
And*p it came to pass, after he had buried him, that he spake to his sons, saying, When I am dead, then bury me in the sepulchre wherein the man of God is buried; lay my bones beside his bones:
For*p the saying which he cried by the word of the Lord*s against the altar in Beth–el, and against all the houses of the high places which are in the cities of Samaria, shall surely come to pass.

After*p this thing Jeroboam returned not from his evil way, but made again of the lowest of the people priests of the high places: whosoever would, he consecrated him, and he became one of the priests of the high places.
And*p this thing became sin unto the house of Jeroboam, even to cut it off, and to destroy it from off the face of the earth.
1 Kings 14
At*p that time Abijah the son of Jeroboam fell sick.

And*p Jeroboam said to his wife, Arise, I pray thee, and disguise thyself, that thou be not known to be the wife of Jeroboam; and get thee to Shiloh: behold, there is Ahijah the prophet, which told me that I should be king over this people.
And*p take with thee ten loaves, and cracknels, and a cruse of honey, and go to him: he shall tell thee what shall become of the child.
And*p Jeroboam's wife did so, and arose, and went to Shiloh, and came to the house of Ahijah. But Ahijah could not see; for his eyes were set by reason of his age.

And*p the Lord*s said unto Ahijah, Behold, the wife of Jeroboam cometh to ask a thing of thee for her son; for he is sick: thus and thus shalt thou say unto her: for it shall be, when she cometh in, that she shall feign herself to be another woman.
